title: 114_hr591
content: The Act may be cited as the "Engineering Biology Research and Development Act of 2015". The Congress finds that cellular and molecular processes can be utilized to develop new products, processes, and systems that benefit society, enhance national security, and boost the economy. Engineering biology requires a diverse set of skills and long-term research and development to achieve breakthroughs, necessitating government investment. The Federal Government plays a crucial role in advancing engineering biology by investing in tools and technologies to support research and development. Without government support, the United States risks falling behind other countries in this emerging field. The United States is at risk of losing its competitive lead in engineering biology without investing in a National Engineering Biology Initiative to establish new research directions, improve coordination, drive technology transfer, and ensure optimal returns on Federal investment. The National Engineering Biology Initiative is needed to maintain the US's competitive edge in engineering biology by establishing new research directions, improving coordination, driving technology transfer, and ensuring optimal returns on Federal investment. The Act defines key terms such as "Advisory Committee," "biomanufacturing," and "engineering biology." The Act defines key terms such as "Interagency Committee" and "Program" related to the National Engineering Biology Research and Development Program. The National Engineering Biology Research and Development Program is established under SEC. 4. The President will implement a National Engineering Biology Research and Development Program to advance societal well-being, national security, and economic productivity through research at the intersection of biological, physical, and information sciences, supporting social science research, and expanding the number of researchers, educators, and students with engineering biology training. The National Engineering Biology Research and Development Program aims to advance societal well-being, national security, and economic productivity through new products, processes, and technologies. It also focuses on expanding the number of researchers, educators, and students with engineering biology training, accelerating research commercialization by the private sector, and improving interagency coordination of Federal Government activities related to engineering biology. Program activities include sustained support for research and development through grants to individual investigators. The National Engineering Biology Research and Development Program includes sustained support for engineering biology research and development through grants to individual investigators, interdisciplinary teams, joint projects funded by multiple agencies, and interdisciplinary research centers. It also focuses on education and training of undergraduate and graduate students. The National Engineering Biology Research and Development Program includes technology development, education of students in interdisciplinary research, tracking economic benefits, and accelerating commercialization of new products and technologies. The National Engineering Biology Research and Development Program aims to accelerate the commercialization of new products, processes, and technologies through precompetitive research, public-private partnerships, entrepreneurship education, and support for startup companies. The National Engineering Biology Research and Development Program supports the formation of startup companies through programs like the Small Business Innovation Research Program. It also aims to expand participation by reaching out to undergraduate and minority-serving institutions and promoting research collaborations. Program activities consider ethical, legal, environmental, and societal issues. Program activities under the National Engineering Biology Research and Development Program address ethical, legal, environmental, and societal issues, including safeguards against unintended material release. This involves supporting research in social sciences and integrating it with engineering biology research and development. The National Engineering Biology Research and Development Program focuses on integrating biology research with engineering, disseminating research results, and incorporating public input through discussions and outreach activities. The President will establish an interagency committee on engineering biology, including representatives from various agencies. The committee will be responsible for overseeing public discussions and outreach activities related to engineering biology. The Interagency Committee, selected by the Director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy, will oversee the planning, management, and coordination of the Program. It will provide interagency coordination, establish goals and priorities, and develop a strategic plan every 5 years. The Program will develop a strategic plan every 5 years to guide its activities, including support for interdisciplinary engineering biology research, education, public outreach, and ethical considerations. The Program will develop a strategic plan every 5 years to guide its activities, including support for interdisciplinary engineering biology research, education, public outreach, and ethical considerations. The Program will also propose an annually coordinated interagency budget to ensure robust research and development portfolio in engineering biology. The Program will maintain a robust engineering biology research and development portfolio, ensure balanced funding, utilize Federal programs like SBIR and STTR, and consider Advisory Committee recommendations. The Interagency Committee will consider recommendations from various groups and prepare an annual report for submission to relevant committees, including the Program budget for the fiscal year. The Interagency Committee prepares an annual report for submission to relevant committees, including the Program budget for the fiscal year and an assessment of how Federal agencies are implementing the plan. It also includes details on Small Business Innovation Research and Small Business Technology Transfer awards. SEC. 5. ADVISORY COMMITTEE. The President shall designate an advisory committee on engineering biology research and development with at least 12 members from various sectors to assess the progress, need for revisions, balance of activities and funding, and the impact of Program priorities on maintaining US leadership in engineering biology. The Advisory Committee on engineering biology research and development will assess the Program priorities, management, and ethical considerations to maintain US leadership. Reports will be submitted every 3 years to the President and relevant committees. The Advisory Committee on engineering biology research and development will report every 3 years to the President and relevant committees on its findings and recommendations to improve the Program. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Advisory Committee. SEC. 6. EXTERNAL REVIEW OF ETHICAL, LEGAL, ENVIRONMENTAL, AND SOCIETAL ISSUES. The Director of the National Science Foundation will convene a workshop with the National Academies to review ethical, legal, environmental, and societal issues related to engineering biology research. The workshop aims to assess current research, identify gaps, and provide recommendations within 12 months of the Act's enactment. A report to Congress is due within 2 years. The Director of the National Science Foundation will transmit a summary report to Congress containing the findings of a workshop convened to address research needs identified within 2 years of the Act's enactment. SEC. 7. AGENCY ACTIVITIES. The National Science Foundation under the Program supports basic research at the intersection of biological, physical, and information sciences, research on environmental and social effects of engineering biology, provides research instrumentation support, and awards grants for graduate students and postdoctoral researchers. The National Science Foundation supports basic research in engineering biology disciplines and awards grants for graduate students and postdoctoral fellows. The Department of Commerce, as part of the Program, establishes a bioscience research program to advance engineering biology and biomanufacturing. The Program aims to advance engineering biology and biomanufacturing by creating new data tools, providing access to advanced facilities, and offering technical expertise for the development of guidelines and safeguards. The Department of Energy, as part of the Program, is responsible for specific tasks related to these goals. The Department of Energy is responsible for conducting research, development, and application activities in engineering biology disciplines, including synthetic biology, biofuel development, biobased materials, and environmental remediation. They also provide access to advanced facilities and resources for industry and higher education institutions. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration conducts research in engineering biology fields, including synthetic biology, Earth and space sciences, aeronautics, space technology, and space exploration as part of the Program. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration conducts research in engineering biology fields, including synthetic biology, Earth and space sciences, aeronautics, space technology, and space exploration. The Program also involves awarding grants for graduate students and postdoctoral fellows to conduct engineering biology research in an industry setting. The Environmental Protection Agency supports research on the environmental impact of engineering biology products, processes, and systems.
